title-group.article-title: Influence of the simultaneous addition of bentonite and cellulose fibers on the mechanical and barrier properties of starch composite-films

article-meta.aff: Department of Chemical and Food Engineering, Federal University of Santa Catarina, PO Box 476, Florianopolis, SC 88040 900, Brazil

author-notes.corresp: J.B. Laurindo, Department of Chemical and Food Engineering, Federal University of Santa Catarina, PO Box 476, Florianopolis, SC 88040 900, Brazil Email: joao@enq.ufsc.br

abstract.p: The addition of nanoclay or cellulose fibers has been presented in the literature as a suitable alternative for reinforcing starch films. The aim of the present work was to evaluate the effect of the simultaneous incorporation of nanoclay (bentonite) and cellulose fibers on the mechanical and water barrier properties of the resultant composite-films. Films were prepared by casting with 3% in weight of cassava starch, using glycerol as plasticizer (0.30 g per g of starch), cellulose fibers at a concentration of 0.30 g of fibers per g of starch and nanoclay (0.05 g clay per g starch and 0.10 g clay per g starch). The addition of cellulose fibers and nanoclay increased the tensile strength of the films 8.5 times and the Young modulus 24 times but reduced the elongation capacity 14 times. The water barrier properties of the composite-films to which bentonite and cellulose fibers were added were approximately 60% inferior to those of starch films. Diffractograms showed that the nanoclay was intercalated in the polymeric matrix. These results indicate that the simultaneous addition of bentonite and cellulose fibers is a suitable alternative to increase the tensile strength of the films and decrease their water vapor permeabilities.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Starches from different sources can be used to prepare films and coatings with different properties indicating that these carbohydrates are promising materials in this regard (Avérous et al., 2001; Larotonda et al., 2005; Mali et al., 2005). However, films formed from starch are brittle and difficult to handle. Plasticizers are normally added to the film-forming solution before casting and drying procedures, as a way to overcome the brittleness of the films. Unfortunately, plasticizers generally increase the hygroscopicity of films, decreasing their water vapor permeability values (Gontard et al., 1993; Krochta and Mulder-Johnston, 1997; Müller et al., 2008).

Starch-based films have low permeability to gases but relatively high permeability to water vapor. However, for many possible applications, the main obstacle to the use of this kind of film as packaging material is its mechanical properties. Films with thickness of approximately 100 µm do not resist the efforts to which they are submitted when used to produce packaging. Thus, the improvement of their resistance to tension and puncture is important to make their use possible (Funke et al., 1998, Garcia et al., 2000; Gáspar et al., 2005; Lourdin et al., 1997; Müller et al., 2008; Wollerdorfer and Bader, 1998). Besides, starch-based films are very sensitive to high relative humidity (RH). It is well known that starch-based films can roll or bend spontaneously at high RH and become difficult to handle. According to Godbillot et al. (2006) and Müller et al. (2008), water interaction and its mobility in starch-based films depend on both plasticizer concentration and RH range.

In order to improve starch-based film characteristics, many researchers reported results on the addition of natural fibers as a suitable reinforcing component for thermoplastic materials. Most of these works focused on the mechanical properties of films and have showed that fiber incorporation increases the tensile strength and elasticity modulus of films and decreases their elongation capacity (Avérous et al., 2001; Curvelo et al., 2001; Dufresne and Vignon, 1998; Follain et al., 2006; Gáspar et al., 2005; Ma et al., 2005).

Concerning the barrier properties, Dufresne and Vignon (1998) and Funke et al. (1998) reported that the addition of fibers decreased the water vapor permeability (Kw) of starch-based films. This behavior was attributed to the low hygroscopicity of cellulose fibers. The Kw depends on the simultaneous effect of water diffusivity in the polymeric matrix (Dw) and on the solubility coefficient of the water in the film (β) (Krochta and Miller, 1997; Larotonda et al., 2005; Müller et al., 2008). Larotonda et al. (2005) determined the Kw, Dw and β values of Kraft paper impregnated with starch acetate. The β value was calculated through the first derivative of the film water sorption isotherm in relation to the water activity (aw), divided by the water vapor pressure (at the sorption isotherm temperature). Since the film’s Kw is proportional to the product of β and Dw, the values of Dw were determined from Kw and β values, at three RH gradient ranges.

Moore et al. (2006) studied the influence of β and Dw on the water vapor permeability of keratin films plasticized with glycerol and reported that the Kw value increased almost six times when 0.09 g glycerol per g keratin was added. This result was explained by the high increase of β, while Dw did not change significantly. Variability in film thickness and density was also described as influencing Kw of keratin films. Müller et al. (2008) showed results for starch-based films that were qualitatively similar to results reported by Moore and coworkers. For the higher RH range (ΔRH = 64–90%), the β values increased for films plasticized with glycerol and sorbitol, while Dw values did not change significantly. These results indicated that Kw values are dependent on the solubility coefficient (β) of the water in the film. Information concerning the influence of fiber addition on the water vapor permeability of starch films is rare in the literature (Imam et al., 2005).

On the other hand, the incorporation of nanoclays in the formulation of films has been reported as another good alternative to improve starch-based film characteristics (Yu et al., 2006). Bentonitic clays are impure aluminum phyllosilicates consisting mainly of montmorillonite. These nanoclays are cheap, with high specific surface area, and can delaminate, leading to good interaction with macromolecules (Weiss et al., 2006). Thus, they have been used for reinforcing starch-based films and for reducing their water vapor permeabilities, without reducing their biodegradability (Cyras et al., 2008; Park et al., 2003; Yu et al., 2006). The starch–nanoclays interactions are increased by exfoliating the nanoclay before and during the mixture, which is explained by the increased surface area (Chiou et al., 2005). Nanoclay dispersion reportedly reduces the diffusion coefficient of water through the films, due to an increase of the structure tortuosity, property that is very used to explain diffusion in porous media (Cyras et al., 2008; Park et al., 2003).

The films made in this work were proposed to be used as packaging material. Therefore, the aim of this work was to investigate how the simultaneous addition of cellulose fibers and nanoclays improves the mechanical and moisture barrier properties of films, and to verify how fiber and nanoclay addition affect the relative influences of the solubility coefficient (β) and diffusion coefficient (Dw) on the water vapor permeability (Kw) of starch films. These results are not available in the literature and are very important to evaluate possible applications of these films as packaging material.

sec.title: Raw materials and film preparation
sec.p: Films were prepared by casting, from cassava starch suspension with 3% in weight of starch (Yoki Alimentos S.A., Paranavai, Paraná – Brazil), using glycerol as plasticizer (0.30 g per g of starch), cellulose fibers at a concentration at 0.30 g fibers per g of starch and nanoclay (0.05 g clay per g of starch and 0.10 g clay per g of starch). The bentonite Na+ clay was supplied by Buschle and Lepper S.A. (San Justo, Buenos Aires – Argentina). Eucalypt cellulose fibers were softwood short fibers measuring 1.2 mm, from Klabin S.A. (Lages, Santa Catarina – Brazil).

Before the preparation of reinforced starch films (with nanoclay), 300 mL of a suspension of water, glycerol and nanoclay was prepared and stirred for 24 h. For films added fiber was prepared as an aqueous suspension of cellulose fibers (1:40), to facilitate the incorporation of these fibers to the starch suspension. The films were prepared according to the casting technique so called After adding the starch, the mixture was heated at 67 °C for 60 min in a thermostatic bath (Tecnal, TE184, Brazil). A total of 50 g of the film-forming mixture were poured into 0.14 m diameter pexiglass plates and dried at 40 °C for 10 h in a forced air oven. The dried films were conditioned at 25 °C in a desiccator with RH of 58% (saturated solution of sodium bromide [NaBr]). The formulations of the films are given in Table 1. Different film formulations were prepared in order to allow 10 replicates of the mechanical tests and three replicates of the water vapor permeability tests. Table 1.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Scanning electron micrographies of film samples were obtained using a Philips XL-scanning electron microscope (SEM). The samples were coated with a fine gold layer before obtaining the micrographies. All samples were examined using an accelerating voltage of 10 kV.

The moisture of the films was determined in triplicate, by the gravimetric method, after drying at 105 °C for 24 h, and expressed in g water per g dry mass. Their thicknesses were measured using a Digimatic digital external micrometer with exactness of ±0.001 mm (Mitutoyo Co., Japan) at 10 different points of the film. For determining film density, samples of 2 cm × 2 cm were maintained in a desiccator with phosphorus pentoxide (0% RH) for 20 days and weighed. Thus, dry matter densities were calculated by Equation (1): (1) where, A is the film area (4 cm2), δ the film thickness (cm), m the film dry mass (g) and ρ the dry matter density of the film (g cm–3; Larotonda et al., 2005). The film density was expressed as the average of 10 determinations.

The moisture sorption isotherms of the films were determined through the static method, using saturated saline solutions to obtain different RHs (Bell and Labuza, 2000). The Guggenheim–Anderson–de Boer (GAB) model (Equation 2) was used to represent the experimental equilibrium data. In this equation, the parameter Xw is the equilibrium moisture (g water per g dry mass), m0 is the monolayer water content, C is the Guggenheim constant, which represents the sorption heat of the first layer and k is the sorption heat of the multilayers. The GAB model parameters were determined by nonlinear regression, using the Statistica Software 6.0 (Statsoft, United States). (2)

The water vapor permeabilities (Kw) of the films were determined in appropriate diffusion cells (Sarantópoulos et al., 2002), using three different RH gradient ranges (ΔRH1 = 2–33%, ΔRH2 = 33–64% and ΔRH3 = 64–90%). The water vapor permeability was calculated using Equation (3): (3) where δ is the average film thickness, A is the film permeation area (0.005 m2), aw1 (RH1 per 100) is the water activity in the chamber, aw2 (RH2 per 100) is the water activity inside the cell, ps is the water vapor pressure at the experimental system temperature (25 °C) and W = G/t (g of water h–1) was calculated using the linear regression of mass variation over time, under steady state permeation condition.

The solubility coefficients of water in the films, β, (that is, the partition coefficient of water between air and film) were determined according to Larotonda et al. (2005), through the first derivative of the moisture sorption isotherm of the film (GAB model) in relation to the water activity (aw), divided by the water vapor pressure, ps, at the sorption isotherm temperature. Physically, the coefficient β is the partition coefficient of water between air and film and is given by Equation (4): (4) where C, m0 and k are the adjustment parameters of the GAB model and β is given in g of water per g of dry solid × Pa.

The water diffusion coefficients through the films (Dw) can be determined through the water vapor permeability (Kw), the solubility coefficient of water in the film (β) and the density of the film (ρS; Equation (5)). For the almost-linear portion of the water sorption isotherm, one can write: (5)

X-ray diffractometry of bentonite nanoclay, starch–glycerol films (WN) and composite-films (5N, 10N, 5NF and 10NF), conditioned at 25 °C and RH of 58% for 48 h, were performed with a Philips X’Pert diffractometer – Netherlands, using copper radiation Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å), voltage of 40 kV and operation current of 30 mA. All assays were performed with 2θ = 3 ° e 2θ = 60 °, and the results were treated by the Bragg Law (Equation 7), which is used in crystallography to relate the diffraction angle and the distance between two molecular layers: (7) where n is an integer number; λ is the wave length of the incident X-ray; d is the interlayer spacing and θ is the diffraction angle.

The mechanical properties of the films were determined though tension tests, using the TA-XT2i texture analyzer (Surrey – England), in accordance to ASTM-882-00 (2000). The dimensions of film samples used in tests were 25 mm × 100 mm, cut with sharp scissors. Samples were clamped between grips and force and deformation data were recorded during extension at 50 mm min–1, with an initial distance between the grips of 50 mm. In this way, the tensile strength (MPa), elasticity modulus (MPa) and relative deformation at break (%) were determined from 10 replicates for each film formulation.
The analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Tukey test (p ≤ 0.05) were performed using Statistica Software – Statsoft, Tulsa, United States, for comparing the properties of different film formulations.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p:
Micrographs of the film surfaces exposed to the drying air and of fractured samples for WN (control), 5N and 5NF are presented in Figure 1. The WN and 5N had wrinkled surface without pores or fissures. The fracture micrographs show homogeneous and dense structures. Cellulose fibers were homogeneously distributed both transversally and longitudinally in sample 5NF with the cellulose fibers well cemented by the starch matrix indicating material compatibility. The micrographs for samples 10N and 10NF (not shown) are similar to those of samples 5N and 5NF. Similar results were reported by Müller et al. (2009) for composites formed by starch and cellulose fibers. Figure 1.
Scanning electron microscopy of surface × 200 (superscript s) and fracture × 500 (superscript f) of the samples WN, 5N and 5NF.

sec.title: Crystallinity
sec.p:
The diffractograms of bentonite nanoclay and of 10NF, 10N, 5NF, 5N and WN film samples are presented in Figure 2. The diffractograms of bentonite nanoclay show a main crystallinity peak at 2θ = 6.5 ° and secondary peaks at 2θ = 11.7 ° and 2θ = 19.8 °. Cyras et al. (2008) reported crystallinity data on natural sodium montmorillonite (MMT Na+) that showed an intense crystallinity peak at 2θ = 7.3 °. The secondary peaks can be explained by the presence of a mixture of clay minerals, but they are not important in the diffractograms of the films, maybe due to the nanoclay exfoliation. Film sample formed only with starch and glycerol (WN) appeared to be semicrystalline, with a dominance of amorphous regions, as has been reported by the literature (Müller et al., 2009; Rindlav-Westling et al., 1998; Van Soest and Vliegenthart, 1997). Figure 2.
Diffractogram of film samples (10NF, 10N, 5NF, 5N and WN) and bentonite. The detail highlights the main peak of the composites and nanoclay and their interlayer spacing.

The incorporation of nanoclay in the films caused a shift of the main peak to the left, indicating an increase of the interlayer spacing (d001). This behavior can be associated to the intercalation of nanoclay into the polymeric matrix. Cyras et al. (2008), Wilhelm et al. (2003) and Park et al. (2002) credited this peak shift to the strong polar interactions between hydroxyl groups present in the glycerol, water and starch with nanoclay ions. The main peaks observed for the nanoclay and for the composite-films are presented in the detail of Figure 2. A shift of the crystalline peak of the nanoclay was observed (2θ = 6.5 ° to 2θ = 4.8 °), as well as an increase of the interlayer spacing from 13.6 Å to 18.7 Å in the sample 5NF, and to 17.9 Å in the sample 10NF. Wilhelm et al. (2003) attributed the increase of the interlayer spacing to the nanoclay dispersion into the polymeric matrix, and that the increase of nanoclay concentration decreases the intercalation. This is in agreement with the results observed in the present work, because samples with 0.05 g of nanoclay per g of dry matter presented larger interlayer spacing than samples with 0.10 g of nanoclay per g of dry matter.

The literature reported results about the properties of composite-films prepared from starch, nanoclay and cellulose fibers. Film samples prepared with starch and fibers presented peaks at 2θ = 22.6 °, with interlayer spacing of 3.9 Å, disregarding the nanoclay concentration. Ma et al. (2005) reported data about the crystallinity of films prepared with starch and cellulose fibers, which are in agreement with the results reported in this work.

sec.title: Thickness, moisture content and density of composite films
sec.p:
Moisture content, thickness and density of control and composite films (WN, 5N, 10N, 5NF and 10NF) are given in Table 2. The thickness of the samples ranged from 95 to 108 µm and was not significantly different (p > 0.05), indicating that the weight control of the film-forming solution is sufficient to control film thickness. Moreover, film samples WN, 5N and 10N were significantly different (p < 0.05) in moisture content, which could be explained by the balancing hydrophilic behavior of the nanoclay. However, the addition of cellulose fibers reduced the film moisture content as previously reported by Curvelo et al. (2001) and Müller et al. (2009), who attributed this reduction to the lower hygroscopicity of cellulose fibers. Table 2.

The density values of composite films of starch-nanoclay-cellulose fibers are similar to those reported by Müller et al. (2009) for films prepared with starch and cellulose fibers and by Dias et al. (2010) for films prepared with rice flour and cellulose fibers. Films containing nanoclay alone (5N and 10N) or with fibers (5NF and 10NF) had similar densities compared to the control film (WN). The literature has been reporting that the addition of cellulose fibers reduces the density of composite-films, which is explained by the low density of these fibers (Dufresne and Vignon, 1998; Wollerdorfer and Bader, 1998).

sec.title: Water sorption isotherms
sec.p:
Experimental data of sorption isotherms of WN, 5N, 10N, 5NF and 10NF film samples and the fitted GAB models are presented in Figure 3a, while the GAB parameters are given in Table 3. The GAB model fitted the experimental sorption data well. All isotherms presented sigmoidal, which is a characteristic of starchy materials, but the curves ‘shoulders’ (close to aw = 0.03) were reduced with the addition of cellulose fibers. Figure 3.

The composite-films prepared from starch-nanoclay-fibers (5NF and 10NF) had lower equilibrium moisture than the control films (WN) or those films prepared with starch and nanoclay samples (5N and 10N). Avérous et al. (2001) attributed the reduction of the equilibrium moisture to the interactions between the cellulose and the hydrophilic sites of starch, replacing the interaction starch–water. This effect can be verified also by the lower values of the m0 parameter (monolayer moisture) presented by samples 5NF and 10NF (Table 3). Cyras et al. (2008) reported sorption data on composite-films of starch–montmorillonite conditioned at RH = 75%. They observed a clear reduction of the hygroscopicity of the films due to the addition of nanoclay, behavior which they explained by the probable hydrogen bonds between the starch and the montmorillonite layers. A similar behavior was observed for samples prepared with 0.05 g of nanoclay per g of dry starch (5N).

They were obtained directly from the isotherm curve because of its nonlinear behavior.

Figure 3b shows the behavior of the solubility coefficients (β) of water in the films, indicating that the values of this coefficient strongly depend on the range of the air RH (water activity of the film). For aw values lower than 0.6, the solubility coefficient value is conservative, while for higher values of aw this coefficient increased considerably. This behavior was also reported by Müller et al. (2008) and Moore et al. (2006). A direct consequence of this nonlinear behavior of β is the increase of the effective driving force that causes water diffusion through the film. For WN films, this driving force is about 13-fold higher for ΔRH3 than for ΔRH2. As a consequence, the values of Kw evaluated at ΔRH3 are also much higher than those evaluated at ΔRH2. The permeability of the sample 5N was 4.7 times higher at ΔRH2 than at ΔRH1, and 1.9 times higher at ΔRH3 than at ΔRH2. These results are in agreement with the results reported by Müller et al. (2009) on composite-films prepared from cassava starch and cellulose fibers. These authors attributed this permeability increase mainly to the increase of the partition coefficient β.

The exactness of β values depends on the quality of the fit of the GAB model to the sorption data. For comparison, the derivatives of sorption data were also determined by local fitting using low-order polynomial models. The typical difference between the β values calculated by the two procedures was approximately 30%, without a tendency.

The addition of nanoclay decreased the water vapor permeability of samples 5N, 10N, 5NF and 10NF, mainly for ΔRH3 (64–90%), when compared with the values found for WN samples. This result is relevant, because packaging materials are frequently submitted to RH higher than 0.6, for example, when they are protecting foods with water activity higher than 0.6.

The permeability of the sample WN ranged from 1.35 × 10−7 g m−1 h−1 Pa−1 to 12.1 × 10−7 g m−1 h−1 Pa−1 when the RHs were changed from ΔRH1 to ΔRH3, while a variation of 1.15 × 10−7 g m−1 h−1 Pa−1 to 5.14 × 10−7 g m−1 h−1 Pa−1 was observed for 10N samples. These results represent important reductions of Kw. Park et al. (2003) explained this reduction of the water vapor permeability considering that the nanoclays dispersed in the polymeric matrix increase the effective diffusion path of diffusing water molecules.

Composite-films prepared from the simultaneous incorporation of nanoclay and cellulose fibers showed higher water vapor permeabilities than composite-films prepared with starch and nanoclay, probably due to the changes caused by cellulose fibers in the composite structure. However, it is important to remark that, in all cases, the permeabilities of all composite-films were always lower than those of starch films.

The diffusion coefficients of composite-films were always lower than those of starch films. These results are in agreement with the results reported by Cyras et al. (2008) for starch–montmorillonite films. They attributed this behavior to the tortuous way formed by the nanoclay inside the polymeric matrix.

On the other side, as it was discussed before, previous works (Moore et al., 2006, Müller et al., 2009) have reported data indicating that the solubility coefficient of water in the film is another very important property to be considered to explain the reduction of water vapor permeability promoted by the addition of nanoclays and cellulose fibers. These results are in agreement with the results presented in Table 4, which shows that the addition of nanoclay and fibers reduced both the solubility coefficient (β) and the diffusion coefficient (Dw).

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The results of tensile strength (T), elongation at break (ε) and Young modulus (Y) for all film samples are presented in Table 5. The addition of nanoclay or the simultaneous addition of nanoclay and fibers reinforced the starch films, increasing their tensile strength and Young modulus, in agreement with literature results (Curvelo et al., 2001; Cyras et al., 2008; Funke et al., 1998; Ma et al., 2005; Müller et al., 2009; Park et al., 2003; Wilhelm et al., 2003). These results can be explained by the deplasticization of the starch matrix due to the competition for the plasticizer absorption between starch matrix and fibers, as reported by Kunanopparat et al. (2008), and between nanoclay and starch. Cyras et al. (2008), Wilhelm et al. (2003) and Park et al. (2003) reported similar behavior for starch–nanoclay films, and attributed the mechanical reinforcement of the composite-films to the strong interfacial interaction between the nanoclays and the polymeric matrix. The increase of film’s tensile strength can be explained mainly by the action of cellulose fibers (similar tensile strength were found for 10N and WN sample), while Young modulus values were influenced by addition of both nanoclay and cellulose fibers. The influence of nanoclay addition on the elongation capacity of the films depended strongly on the nanoclay concentration, as seen in Table 5. However, the effect of cellulose fibers on this property seems to be dominant.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Simultaneous addition of cellulose fibers and nanoclay significantly increased the tensile strength and Young modulus of starch films but greatly reduced their elongation capacity. Furthermore, the water barrier property of the composite-films prepared with 0.10 g of bentonite per g of dry starch, and 0.30 g of cellulose fibers per g dry starch was about 60% lower than the typical value found for starch-based films. Sample crystallinity suggests that the technique used to prepare the composite-films promoted the intercalation of nanoclay into the polymeric matrix. Thus, these results indicate that the simultaneous addition of bentonite and cellulose fibers is a suitable alternative for increasing the tensile strength of films and for decreasing their water vapor permeabilities.
